title: BDO confirm Grand Slam of Darts representatives as Suzuki and Ashton make debuts
text:
Glen Durrant will be back at the Grand Slam (Picture: Lawrence Lustig)

The BDO have named their eight representatives at this year’s Grand Slam of Darts, all of whom will be taking on the PDC’s finest in Wolverhampton next month.

There was plenty of discussion as to who would get the slots, especially with the anomaly of BDO world champion Glen Durrant now playing in the PDC full time, but not having already qualified for the Grand Slam.

Durrant has indeed been handed one of the BDO’s picks, along with Wesley Harms, Lisa Ashton, Jim Williams, Mikuru Suzuki, Richard Veenstra, Dave Parletti and Wayne Warren.

World Champions Glen Durrant and Mikuru Suzuki amongst the eight confirmed @BDOdarts representatives for the 2019 Grand Slam of Darts ➡️ https://t.co/whq7xSYWiP pic.twitter.com/vg43Nw2ZlE — PDC Darts (@OfficialPDC) October 17, 2019

While women have competed at the Grand Slam before – Anastasia Dobromyslova, Stacy Bromberg and Tricia Wright all appearing in the past – this is the first time since 2010 that any ladies have made it into the tournament as Ashton and Suzuki both make their debuts.

The 32-player field is completed by 16 players from the PDC, earned by winning or finishing runner-up in tournaments over the season, and by eight more PDC players that come through a qualification event on 4 November.

12 of the 16 spots have been filled from the PDC so far, with opportunities still left to grab the final four at the European Championship and World Series of Darts Finals (also the Champions League, but all eight competitors have already qualified).

PDC players qualified for the Grand Slam Michael van Gerwen

Gerwyn Price

Rob Cross

Dimitri van den Bergh

Nathan Aspinall

Daryl Gurney

Gary Anderson

Peter Wright

Michael Smith

Dave Chisnall

Martin Schindler

James Wade

World Cup of Darts runners-up, Steve Lennon and William O’Connor will come in if the European Championship finalists have not already qualified for the Grand Slam.

Ian White and Mensur Suljovic will take the final two spots if the four finalists in the European Championship and World Series Finals have all already qualified.

The Grand Slam picture ahead of the European Championship (Picture: PDC)

It is an annoyingly complicated process to determine those competing in the Wolverhampton event, and we can all just look forward to it getting underway rather than worrying about how the players made it there.

The qualifier on 4 November will be huge for some players, though, as it is a ranking event and £4,000 on offer just for coming bottom of your group.

The winner in Wolverhampton will walk away with a cool £125,000.
